title: Jimmy Kimmelâs Oscars Monologue
description: The 90th Oscars - Live Oscar Sunday March 4th 8 e | 5 p Jimmy's opening monologue from the 2017 #Oscars. SUBSCRIBE to get ...

captions: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.56" dur="5.36">Welcome, and most importantly, congratulations!</text><text start="5.92" dur="2.7">Congratulations to everyone who&#39;s nominated tonight.</text><text start="8.62" dur="2">Thank you for letting me be a part of this.</text><text start="10.62" dur="1.92">I&#39;m excited. I&#39;ve never been to the Oscars before.</text><text start="12.54" dur="1.7">This is my first time here</text><text start="14.24" dur="5.8">and the way you people go through hosts, it&#39;s probably my last time here, so I&#39;m gonna enjoy this while I&#39;m here.</text><text start="20.04" dur="3.9">This broadcast is being watched live by millions of Americans</text><text start="23.94" dur="5.24">and around the world in more than 225 countries that now hate us.</text><text start="29.18" dur="7.28">And I think that is an amazing thing.</text><text start="36.46" dur="5.32">As you know, I don&#39;t have to tell anybody, the country is divided right now.</text><text start="41.78" dur="1.08">I&#39;ve been getting a lot of advice</text><text start="42.86" dur="2">people have been telling me it&#39;s time to bring everyone together</text><text start="44.86" dur="3.7">you need to say something to unite us, and</text><text start="48.56" dur="2.42">let&#39;s just get something straight off the top</text><text start="50.98" dur="3.86">I&#39;m not-- I can&#39;t do that. That&#39;s not-- there&#39;s only one Braveheart</text><text start="54.84" dur="9.34">in this room, and he&#39;s not gonna unite us either.  Okay?</text><text start="64.18" dur="5.52">Mel, you look great. I think the Scientology is working, I really do.</text><text start="69.7" dur="3.66">I&#39;m not the man to unite this country, but it can be done.</text><text start="73.36" dur="1.88">You know, if every person watching this show</text><text start="75.24" dur="3.74">I don&#39;t want to get too serious, but there are millions and millions of people watching right now</text><text start="78.98" dur="3.72">and if every one of you took a minute to reach out to one person</text><text start="82.7" dur="3.14">you disagree with - someone you like - and have a positive</text><text start="85.84" dur="3.26">considerate conversation - not as liberals or conservatives</text><text start="89.1" dur="5.74">as Americans, if we would all do that, we could make America great again. We really could.</text><text start="94.84" dur="2">It starts with us.</text><text start="96.84" dur="4.5">And tonight, in the spirit of healing and bringing people together, I would like to bury the hatchet</text><text start="101.34" dur="7.68">with someone I&#39;ve had issues with.  I would.</text><text start="109.02" dur="3.66">Matt Damon. Now Matt, I&#39;ve known Matt for a long time now.</text><text start="112.68" dur="5.3">You know, I&#39;ve known Matt so long, when I first met Matt, I was the fat one.</text><text start="117.98" dur="4.44">Okay?  True.</text><text start="122.42" dur="2.62">And we&#39;ve had problems. He&#39;s a selfish person.</text><text start="125.04" dur="2.58">Those of you who have worked with him know this.</text><text start="127.62" dur="3.86">But Matt did something very unselfish and I want to commend him for it.</text><text start="131.48" dur="2.76">For real. Matt, as you probably know, could have starred</text><text start="134.24" dur="2">in &quot;Manchester By The Sea&quot;, he was the producer</text><text start="136.24" dur="3.9">it&#39;s nominated for six Oscars including Lead Actor</text><text start="140.14" dur="5.18">and he could have taken that lead actor part for himself.</text><text start="145.32" dur="4.24">But he didn&#39;t, he gave that role to Casey Affleck, his childhood friend.</text><text start="149.56" dur="2.88">He handed what turned out to be an Oscar caliber role</text><text start="152.44" dur="10.48">over to his friend and made a Chinese ponytail movie instead.</text><text start="162.92" dur="5.98">And that movie, &quot;The Great Wall&quot; went on to lose 80 million dollars.</text><text start="168.9" dur="3.06">Smooth move, dumbass.</text><text start="171.96" dur="5.7">See? It&#39;s so easy to reach out and heal. And I want to say-- maybe this is not</text><text start="177.66" dur="3.5">a popular thing to say, but I want to say thank you to President Trump.</text><text start="181.16" dur="7.52">I mean remember last year when it seemed like the Oscars were racist?</text><text start="188.68" dur="1.56">That&#39;s gone!</text><text start="190.24" dur="2.42">Thanks to him.</text><text start="192.66" dur="2.86">What a night. It has been an amazing year for movies.</text><text start="195.52" dur="2.92">Black people saved NASA and white people saved jazz.</text><text start="198.44" dur="5.08">That&#39;s what we call progress.</text><text start="203.52" dur="4.84">A little movie musical named, &quot;La La Land&quot; ties the all time Oscar record</text><text start="208.36" dur="2">it was directed by Damien Chazelle</text><text start="210.36" dur="10.88">Fourteen nominations.  Fourteen nominations: one for every year Damien has been alive.</text><text start="221.24" dur="4.74">Tonight is very important for Damien: if he wins, he&#39;ll be able to go to any college he wants.</text><text start="225.98" dur="2.78">So we wish you the best.</text><text start="228.76" dur="3.82">The movie business is changing. For the first time ever, Amazon is represented</text><text start="232.58" dur="5.6">at the Academy Awards. Amazon is the first streaming service nominated for Best Picture.</text><text start="238.18" dur="3.94">Jeff Bezos is the founder and CEO and I want to say congratulations to Jeff</text><text start="242.12" dur="4.46">you know, and I also want you to know, Jeff, if you win tonight you can expect your Oscar</text><text start="246.58" dur="4.12">to arrive in two to five business days.</text><text start="250.7" dur="3.92">Possibly stolen by a Grubhub delivery man.</text><text start="254.62" dur="2.34">Amazon produced &quot;Manchester By The Sea&quot;</text><text start="256.96" dur="4.32">That was a fun movie, wasn&#39;t it?</text><text start="261.28" dur="3.66">You know if you search for &quot;Manchester By The Sea&quot; on Amazon it says</text><text start="264.94" dur="6.08">&quot;Customers who bought this item also purchased Zoloft.</text><text start="271.02" dur="2.42">I don&#39;t know what&#39;s going on but there are a lot of sad movies this year.</text><text start="273.44" dur="10.9">Of all the nominees, the only happy ending of all the nominees was the one in the middle of &quot;Moonlight&quot;.</text><text start="284.34" dur="5.18">You didn&#39;t watch it, did you?  &quot;Oh we love it so much!&quot;</text><text start="289.52" dur="6.76">The incredible Denzel Washington is nominated for &quot;Fences&quot; - a movie he also directed.</text><text start="296.28" dur="4.88">I don&#39;t know, you&#39;ve probably heard the story of how it came together: apparently Denzel had always wanted</text><text start="301.16" dur="4.46">to work with Denzel, and it just so happened that their schedules worked out</text><text start="305.62" dur="3.36">and the rest is Oscar history. Congratulations to you, my friend.</text><text start="308.98" dur="3.26">We have friends and colleagues visiting from all around the world tonight.</text><text start="312.24" dur="4.38">The great actress from France, Isabelle Huppert, is here with us.</text><text start="316.62" dur="4.34">Isabelle, as you know, is nominated for her performance</text><text start="320.96" dur="4.58">in the movie, &quot;Elle&quot; and on behalf of everyone here, I would like to say</text><text start="325.54" dur="5.72">we didn&#39;t see &quot;Elle&quot; but we absolutely loved it. You were amazing in that film</text><text start="331.26" dur="3.74">and I&#39;m glad Homeland Security let you in tonight. I really am.</text><text start="335" dur="2.16">We are very welcoming to outsiders here in Hollywood.</text><text start="337.16" dur="4.68">We don&#39;t discriminate against people based on what countries they come from</text><text start="341.84" dur="5.88">we discriminate against them based on their age and weight.</text><text start="347.72" dur="3.22">Andrew Garfield lost 40 pounds - where is Andrew?</text><text start="350.94" dur="2">Oh you can barely even see him, he got so thin</text><text start="352.94" dur="4.12">There he is. He lost 40 pounds for his role in the movie, &quot;Silence&quot;.</text><text start="357.06" dur="8.66">It was an astonishing physical transformation that hasn&#39;t been attempted since every actress in every role ever.</text><text start="365.72" dur="3.76">Viggo Mortensen, who is terrific, is nominated for Best Actor</text><text start="369.48" dur="6.66">for his performance in the movie, &quot;Captain Fantastic&quot;</text><text start="376.14" dur="5.44">and it is so well deserved. Too often The Academy only recognizes movies that people have seen.</text><text start="381.58" dur="3.58">And I just think it&#39;s wonderful.</text><text start="385.16" dur="2.3">We are here tonight to honor great actors</text><text start="387.46" dur="5.22">but we&#39;re also here to honor the actors who seem great, but actually really aren&#39;t.</text><text start="392.68" dur="3.62">And of all the &quot;great&quot; actors here in Hollywood</text><text start="396.3" dur="18.74">one in particular has stood the test of time for her many uninspiring and overrated performances.</text><text start="415.04" dur="4.98">See?  That&#39;s what he means.</text><text start="420.02" dur="6.52">And may I say, from her mediocre early work in &quot;The Dear Hunter&quot; and &quot;Out of Africa&quot;</text><text start="426.54" dur="4.14">to her underwhelming performances in &quot;Kramer vs. Kramer&quot; and &quot;Sophie&#39;s Choice&quot;,</text><text start="430.68" dur="4.62">Meryl Streep has phoned it in for more than 50 films</text><text start="435.3" dur="2.94">over the course of her lackluster career.</text><text start="438.24" dur="6.12">This is Meryl&#39;s 20th Oscar nomination.</text><text start="444.36" dur="5.12">Made even more amazing considering the fact that she wasn&#39;t even in a movie this year</text><text start="449.48" dur="2.64">we just wrote her name down out of habit.</text><text start="452.12" dur="3">Meryl, stand up if you would. tags: jimmy;jimmy kimmel;jimmy kimmel live;late night;talk show;funny;comedic;comedy;clip;comedian;mean tweets;oscars;oscar sunday;academy awards;matt damon;ben affleck;we bought a zoo;influencers;oscars 2017
captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="1.86" dur="6.1">The first time I discovered &quot;We Bought a Zoo&quot; was at a multiplex in Burbank, believe it or not.</text><text start="7.96" dur="9.02">The theater was completely empty. And it was magic. It was like it was just me and Matt and the animals.</text><text start="16.98" dur="6.2">So your question is?
Why did you buy this place?</text><text start="23.18" dur="1.48">Why not?</text><text start="24.66" dur="6.78">&quot;Why not?&quot; Makes two words feel like three words.</text><text start="31.44" dur="2.66">I guess I just don&#39;t understand how you can call this place home.</text><text start="34.1" dur="5.76">You know what? Like this. It&#39;s our home.</text><text start="39.86" dur="5.62">He shows you how he&#39;s able to hear words and then repeat them back.</text><text start="45.48" dur="2">I mean I thought you liked me! I thought this was a dream come true for us!</text><text start="47.48" dur="2.38">It&#39;s your dream!</text><text start="49.86" dur="6.06">The thing about Matt is you can see how hard he&#39;s working. It&#39;s so effort-full for him.</text><text start="55.92" dur="5.06">This is a good dream! And it&#39;s got cool animals in it and some pretty great people, too!</text><text start="60.98" dur="3.94">I have goosebumps. I&#39;ve seen that a hundred times, I still have goosebumps.</text><text start="64.92" dur="3.56">We bought a zoo.
We did that.</text><text start="68.48" dur="2.34">He bought a zoo and he made it work.</text><text start="70.84" dur="7.78">That&#39;s the thing about Matt, you know, he has almost no discernible talent, but he works.</text><text start="82.48" dur="3.84">And now to present the award for Best Original Screenplay</text><text start="86.32" dur="15.12">Two-time Academy Award winner Ben Affleck, and guest.</text><text start="101.44" dur="2.22">&quot;And guest,&quot; wow really?</text><text start="103.66" dur="3.76">Yeah, you know, it&#39;s like a plus one.</text><text start="107.42" dur="7.6">I know what a guest is. I actually liked that performance in that movie.</text><text start="115.02" dur="4.46">Really?</text><text start="119.48" dur="5.06">The great Alfred Hitchcock was once asked, &quot;what are the key elements of making a memorable movie?&quot;</text><text start="124.54" dur="7.68">He said, &quot;To make a great film you need three things: the script, the script, and the script.&quot;</text><text start="132.22" dur="5.44">This year&#39;s screenplays proved him right through their creative storytelling and inspirational themes.</text><text start="137.66" dur="4.78">The nominees include a story of two brothers-- oh my God. You gotta be kidding me.</text><text start="142.44" dur="4.56">Wait hold on, come on, what is with the music? Am I being played off, seriously?</text><text start="147" dur="3.02">You can&#39;t play me-- I&#39;m just presenting, you can&#39;t play me off!</text><text start="150.04" dur="2">Why are they playing off the presenter?</text><text start="158.76" dur="2">Wrap it up, we want to go home!</text></transcript>

title: Return of the King won all 11 Oscars it was Nominated For
description: Return of the King, like Ben Hur and Titanic, won 11 Oscars. Unlike them, it has the record for largest clean sweep.

description: 10 horror films that were overlooked for "Best Picture" Oscars! Only 6 horror films till date have been nominated for Best Picture at ...

captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.96" dur="5.68">Only 6 horror films to date have beenÂ 
nominated for Best Picture at the Academy Awards.Â Â </text><text start="14.484" dur="1.906">And just one has won so far!</text><text start="16.39" dur="4.889">ThatâsÂ appallingly bleak for a genre that has pushed the boundaries with its inventive</text><text start="21.279" dur="5.139">storytellingÂ and offered some incredible performances. Here are 10 spine-chilling</text><text start="26.418" dur="5.902">masterpieces that trulyÂ deserved the elusive âBest Pictureâ Oscar!</text><text start="38.269" dur="1.731"> 
Jordan Peeleâs Nope brings togetherÂ Â </text><text start="40" dur="5.56">some of the most talented actors in the industry.
It takes us on a thrilling journey that challengesÂ Â </text><text start="45.56" dur="5.4">our perceptions of what&#39;s possible. The filmÂ 
explores the complexities of human nature,Â Â </text><text start="50.96" dur="5.12">addressing important issues like exploitationÂ 
and the pursuit of entertainment that are tooÂ Â </text><text start="56.08" dur="5.68">often swept under the rug. Nope has unexpectedÂ 
twists and turns that will leave you questioningÂ Â </text><text start="61.76" dur="4.8">everything you thought you knew. While JordanÂ 
Peeleâs previous ventures offered a unique spinÂ Â </text><text start="66.56" dur="7.232">on the slasher and home-invasion horror, Nope isÂ 
an unsettling look at the alien-invasion genre.</text><text start="76.131" dur="3.869"> 
Director Ari Aster&#39;s debutÂ Â </text><text start="80" dur="5.68">feature is a masterclass in building tension andÂ 
creating a sense of dread. From its masterfulÂ Â </text><text start="85.68" dur="4.4">writing to the genuinely disturbingÂ 
staging, Hereditary navigates betweenÂ Â </text><text start="90.08" dur="5.96">heart-wrenching family drama and bone-chillingÂ 
psychological and supernatural terror.Â </text><text start="96.04" dur="4.68">Toni Collette&#39;s portrayal of a grievingÂ 
mother is nothing short of extraordinary,Â Â </text><text start="100.72" dur="4.04">and Aster springs some nastyÂ 
surprises on the characters.Â Â </text><text start="104.76" dur="4.64">It isnât your formulaic horror. The filmÂ 
is a refreshing and poignant take on theÂ Â </text><text start="109.4" dur="5.32">dynamics of a dysfunctional family and aÂ 
beautiful example of visual storytelling.</text><text start="114.72" dur="2.84"> </text><text start="117.56" dur="4.72">This Australian psychological horror filmÂ 
stands out for its portrayal of grief andÂ Â </text><text start="122.28" dur="6.52">eerie monster design. The film explores themes ofÂ loss and motherhood in a truly haunting manner.Â </text><text start="128.8" dur="5.32">Itâs a beautiful metaphor for the complexitiesÂ 
and hardships of being a mother. Essie DavisâÂ Â </text><text start="134.12" dur="4.36">performance is a stand-out and a hugeÂ 
part of why the film is exceptional. TheÂ Â </text><text start="138.48" dur="7.28">Babadook excels in every aspect; itâsÂ 
both terrifying and deeply emotional.</text><text start="145.76" dur="4.84"> 
Robert Eggersâ bleak and austere monochromeÂ Â </text><text start="150.6" dur="5.52">masterpiece encourages multiple interpretations,Â 
constantly making us wonder whatâs real andÂ Â </text><text start="156.12" dur="6.52">whatâs not. The film defies categorization, andÂ 
perhaps such ambiguity restricted it to onlyÂ Â </text><text start="162.64" dur="6.2">receiving a Best Cinematography nomination.
Robert Pattinson and Willem Dafoe knock itÂ Â </text><text start="168.84" dur="4.08">out of the park! Their portrayalÂ 
of two lighthouse keepers losingÂ Â </text><text start="172.92" dur="6">their minds in the middle of nowhere wasÂ 
mesmerizing, intense, and raw. Moreover,Â Â </text><text start="178.92" dur="5.74">the artistic choice to shoot in black andÂ 
white makes every frame a haunting work of art.</text><text start="184.66" dur="5.98"> 
The Texas Chainsaw Massacre is more than justÂ Â </text><text start="190.64" dur="5.72">about Leatherface; it&#39;s a boundary-pushing filmÂ 
that breaks away from traditional horror clichÃ©sÂ Â </text><text start="196.36" dur="6.08">and delivers a visceral experience like no other.
It forces us to confront our darkest fears,Â Â </text><text start="202.44" dur="5.08">and that alone deserves recognition. TheÂ 
film addresses societal issues head-on,Â Â </text><text start="207.52" dur="5.92">exploring themes like family dysfunction andÂ 
the desensitization of violence in our culture.Â </text><text start="213.44" dur="5.08">Who knew a little blood andÂ 
guts could have such depth?</text><text start="218.52" dur="3.44">John Carpenterâs The ThingÂ Â </text><text start="221.96" dur="5.12">isnât your typical alien-invasion monsterÂ 
flick; it transcends genres and becomes aÂ Â </text><text start="227.08" dur="6.72">thrilling study of isolation, paranoia, andÂ 
trust. It&#39;s like a monster movie on steroids!Â </text><text start="233.8" dur="6.2">The ensemble cast of colorful characters are notÂ 
just victims waiting to die; they are complex,Â Â </text><text start="240" dur="5.96">layered individuals being pushed to their limits.
And you can forget CGI; this movie opted forÂ Â </text><text start="245.96" dur="3.04">practical effects that stillÂ 
make your jaw drop today.</text><text start="251" dur="3.92"> 
Frankenstein chroniclesÂ Â </text><text start="254.92" dur="6.16">the quest of a mad scientist who brings aÂ 
terrifying monster to life. This leads toÂ Â </text><text start="261.08" dur="5">a harrowing journey into the dark depthsÂ 
of humanity. If that doesn&#39;t scream &quot;BestÂ Â </text><text start="266.08" dur="5.08">Picture,&quot; I don&#39;t know what does!
Its incredible set designs andÂ Â </text><text start="271.16" dur="5.12">breathtaking cinematography bring toÂ 
life our innermost fears and desires.Â </text><text start="276.28" dur="5.6">Not to mention the legendary Boris Karloff, whoÂ 
brilliantly embodied the monster role with suchÂ Â </text><text start="281.88" dur="6">raw anguish and vulnerability. His performanceÂ 
continues to resonate with audiences today,Â Â </text><text start="287.88" dur="6.2">serving as the epitome of what itÂ 
means to be an iconic movie monster.</text><text start="294.08" dur="3.32">Ridley Scottâs AlienÂ Â </text><text start="297.4" dur="5.28">tackles themes like isolation, survival, andÂ 
the fear of the unknown. It essentially takesÂ Â </text><text start="302.68" dur="5.72">a haunted house set-up and transplants it toÂ 
the gloomy interiors of a futuristic spaceship.Â </text><text start="308.4" dur="4.28">And if you want to talk iconic, theÂ 
chest-burster scene is one of a kind,Â Â </text><text start="312.68" dur="3.56">and nothing compares to theÂ 
level of terror they achieved.Â </text><text start="316.24" dur="3.76">It has received critical acclaimÂ 
for its direction, visual effects,Â Â </text><text start="320" dur="6.652">and screenplay. It even won the Oscar forÂ 
Best Visual Effects! So why stop there?</text><text start="328.48" dur="4.2"> 
Alright, let&#39;s be real here. TheÂ Â </text><text start="332.68" dur="5.88">Shining was and still is a groundbreaking pieceÂ 
of cinema. Stanley Kubrick&#39;s vision, combinedÂ Â </text><text start="338.56" dur="5.64">with Jack Nicholson&#39;s chilling performance,Â 
created a sensory experience like no other.Â </text><text start="344.2" dur="5.2">Stephen King and Kubrick rejuvenated the genreÂ 
with this one. The tension and suspense areÂ Â </text><text start="349.4" dur="5.48">palpable. The Overlook Hotel serves more thanÂ 
a mere backdrop; itâs a character in its ownÂ Â </text><text start="354.88" dur="6.12">right. Its sprawling, labyrinthine layout andÂ 
grandiose isolation are immediately unsettling,Â Â </text><text start="361" dur="4.88">creating a sense of entrapment and disorientation. Besides, its influence on theÂ Â </text><text start="365.88" dur="5.32">charactersâespecially Jack TorranceâheightensÂ 
the psychological horror. It seems to preyÂ Â </text><text start="371.2" dur="3.6">on their fears and weaknesses,Â 
driving them towards madness.Â </text><text start="376.36" dur="4.92">Kubrick&#39;s use of steady, gliding cameraÂ 
shots through the empty corridors and vast,Â Â </text><text start="381.28" dur="8.12">echoing spaces amplifies the feelingÂ 
of solitude and vulnerability.</text><text start="392.434" dur="0.846">Hitchcock created aÂ Â </text><text start="393.28" dur="5.56">taboo film that breaks all the unsaid rulesÂ 
for films in the 60s. From women in bras toÂ Â </text><text start="398.84" dur="5.32">unmarried couples sharing a bed, Psychoâs themesÂ of voyeurism forever changed the landscape ofÂ Â </text><text start="404.16" dur="7.12">horror and suspense. The film&#39;s exploitation andÂ 
exploration of identity, guilt, and obsessionÂ Â </text><text start="411.28" dur="5.28">resonates with viewers on a profound level.
Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh give stellarÂ Â </text><text start="416.56" dur="4.56">performances with depth and nuanceÂ 
that the film would be amiss without.Â </text><text start="421.12" dur="2.96">If you haven&#39;t taken the timeÂ 
to sit down and watch Psycho,Â Â </text><text start="424.08" dur="6.92">you are missing out on one of the most famous,Â 
controversial, and influential films of all time.</text><text start="431" dur="4.96">For more âBest Pictureâ Oscar snubs outside ofÂ 
horror, check out the link in the descriptionÂ Â </text><text start="435.96" dur="9.08">below and donât forget to like and subscribeÂ 
to Flickside for more great film content.</text></transcript>
